t: Ecclesiastes 10
As*pn dead flies give perfume a bad smell, so*ld a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor.
The*ln heart of the wise inclines to the right, but*ld the heart of the fool to the left.
Even*ln as fools walk along the road, they*ld lack sense and*ld show everyone how stupid they are.
If*ln a ruler’s anger rises against you, do*ld not leave your post; calmness*ld can lay great offenses to rest.
There*pn is an evil I have seen under the sun, the*ld sort of error that arises from a ruler:
Fools*ln are put in many high positions, while*ld the rich occupy the low ones.
I*ln have seen slaves on horseback, while*ld princes go on foot like slaves.
Whoever*pn digs a pit may fall into it; whoever*ld breaks through a wall may be bitten by a snake.
Whoever*ln quarries stones may be injured by them; whoever*ld splits logs may be endangered by them.
If*pn the ax is dull and*ld its edge unsharpened, more*ln strength is needed, but*ld skill will bring success.
If*pn a snake bites before it is charmed, the*ld charmer receives no fee.
Words*pn from the mouth of the wise are gracious, but*ld fools are consumed by their own lips.
At*ln the beginning their words are folly; at*ld the end they are wicked madness—
and*ld fools multiply words. No*pn one knows what is coming— who*ld can tell someone else what will happen after them?
The*pn toil of fools wearies them; they*ld do not know the way to town.
Woe*pn to the land whose king was a servant and*ld whose princes feast in the morning.
Blessed*ln is the land whose king is of noble birth and*ld whose princes eat at a proper time— for*ld strength and not for drunkenness.
Through*pn laziness, the rafters sag; because*ld of idle hands, the house leaks.
A*pn feast is made for laughter, wine*ld makes life merry, and*ld money is the answer for everything.
Do*pn not revile the king even in your thoughts, or*ld curse the rich in your bedroom, because*ln a bird in the sky may carry your words, and*ld a bird on the wing may report what you say.
